Riot police rushed to the demonstrators and caused chaos. During the commotion, a man in a red shirt attacked a reporter and a first aider was arrested for possessing three pairs of scissors and saline water. [size=more than 100]

Many journalists and policemen were hospitalised with severe burns from having corrosive liquids being thrown at them by rioters. There was an armed physical clash between rioters and an elderly man (one of was armed with a knife) near the Tai Hing Estate market that resulted in three hospitalised. Late evening, anti-ELAB demonstrators set fire at Heung Sze Wui Rd, vandalising the nearby Choy Yee Bridge MTR station, the Tai Hing Government Offices, and 'pro-establishment' restaurant businesses. Social workers and police officers arrived to mediate the situation and disperse rioters respectively. [size=at least 100]

The demonstrators covered their faces and painted the Mall's floor with popular demonstration slogans. At the Kwun Tong MTR Station, police used pepper spray against demonstrators, onlookers and journalists. At around 5.30pm when a team of police officers were investigating a case of criminal damage at the station, an unidentified man attacked a police officer in the neck. The police chased down the assailant and arrested two people. [size=a dozen]

NOTES: On 3 November 2019, nearly 100 people gathered around 5pm at Taikoo Shing in Eastern District (Hong Kong) to demonstrate against the government and the mask ban. They chanted slogans such as 'five demands, not one less' and sang 'glory to Hong Kong'. The situation escalated as one pro-Beijing demonstrator started attacking other people and got beaten by the crowd. A district councillor got his ear bitten off while he tried to stop a man with knife from attacking people. After an hour, police entered the mall and dispersed people with pepper sprays and guns. Police reported that 6 people were injured and 3 were arrested. A reporter from the Stand News and another student journalist from the Hong Kong Baptist University were also arrested. [size=nearly 100]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 8 November 2019, students at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Sai Kung District (New Territories, Hong Kong) gathered in the morning on campus to demonstrate against the police after the student who fell from a parking lot during a demonstration on 3 and 4 November was confirmed to be dead. They also demonstrated against the university by marching to the university president's residence place. They shouted outside the residence to demand the university to further investigate the police's use of force. Some students vandalised the campus in the afternoon. In the same district, nearly 100 people gathered to commemorate the student as well. Demonstrators set fire to an electrical control box outside Sheung Tak Plaza and damaged the Tseung Kwan O MTR Station. Police dispersed the crowd at the MTR station with tear gas. A reporter was reportedly hit by rubber bullets during the clashes and taken away for treatment. [size=nearly 100]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 8 November 2019, anti-government demonstrators gathered at Mong Kok in Yau Tsim Mong District (Kowloon City, Hong Kong) at night after the student who fell from a parking lot during a demonstration on 4 November was confirmed to be dead. They blocked roads and destroyed the Mong Kok MTR Station. It was reported that a plain clothes police shot real bullets near Pitt St at Yau Ma Tei. During the demonstration, 9 people in black clothes attacked a photographer at Mongkok, reportedly because the media company for which he worked was pro-government. They attacked the photographer with iron sticks and destroyed the camera. The victim was sent to the hospital. On the same night, commemoration events for the deceased student took place across Hong Kong, and demonstrators walked to streets and blocked roads in multiple districts. [size=no report]

A demonstrator - an off-duty firefighter - was arrested for throwing a Molotov bomb onto the streets. A journalist and a photographer were attacked by demonstrators during the early hours at Mongkok reportedly because the media company for which they worked was pro-government. The demonstrators asked to see the journalist's press pass, before pushing him to the floor and beating the photographer to force the pair to leave the scene. [size=no report]

NOTES: On 17 November 2019, hundreds of students from the Hong Kong Polytechnic University (Kowloon City District, Hong Kong) clashed heavily with the police while defending the campus and the sieged cross-harbour tunnel with umbrellas, petrol bombs and arrows from early morning until midnight after a week of a citywide demonstration against the extradition bill and increased police brutality. Police fired rubber bullets, tear gases and water cannons to push the front line towards the campus, and threatened to fire live ammunition if students did not leave the campus via an instructed path. It was reported that many students, medical workers and journalists without police-approved credentials tried to leave via the instructed path but got arrested. A police officer was hit by an arrow in his leg. An armoured police truck was reported to be set on fire. It was also reported that police used a controversial Long Range Acoustic Device for a very short time that caused discomfort in people's ears. By the night of 17 November, all entries to the campus had been sealed by the police. [size=hundreds]

On 19 November 2019, 4 unknown individuals wearing black clothes set fire around 3am to a print factory at Mong Kok, Yau Tsim Mong District (Kowloon City, Hong Kong) which printed for the anti-CCP newspaper, The Epoch Times. [size=4]

On 7 December 2019, around 2000-3000 people attended a pro-government rally in Harbour Road Garden in Wan Chai, Hong Kong to express their view that the District Council election in November was considered unfair and the election results failed to reflect true public opinion. Demonstrators sang the Chinese national anthem, shouted pro-police slogans and held national flags and HKSAR flags. During the demonstration, a student reporter from Baptist University was hurt in the leg by demonstrators who pushed him around, scolded him, and followed him as he left, before police instructed them to return to the rally. [size=2000-3000]

During the march, it was reported that a reporter from Ming Pao was surrounded, and then pushed and kicked by demonstrators. His reporter mask was also ripped off by demonstrators. Riot police came to disperse the group of demonstrators. The reporter sustained injuries in his right calf. [size=over 100]

On 18 April 2020, more than a dozen unidentified persons assaulted and took away the mobile phones of many reporters in Yuanyang County (Xinxiang City, Henan Province), where the reporters were conducting interviews at a cemetery. The assault took place after four children suffocated to death after being buried alive at an illegal construction site. ACcording to the county Publicity Department, family members of the children assaulted the reporters as they were not happy with the interviews. The mobile phones were returned to the reporters by the subdistrict office on 21 April 2020, with all contents related to the incident having been erased. [size=more than a dozen]

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 10 May 2020, people gathered in Harbour City, MOKO, and Langham Place in Yau Tsim Mong District (Hong Kong) for the 'Sing with You' rally. They chanted anti-ELAB slogans and also called for the five demands. Riot police entered the malls to warn the crowd to disperse, as they were violating the COVID-19 restriction order. At MOKO mall, after a drinks bottle was thrown from a higher floor, police fired pepper ball rounds. A 13-year-old student journalist was arrested in Harbour City. In the evening in Mong Kok, a group of demonstrators blocked roads along Nathan Road, while the police fired pepper spray towards people who gathered to shout at the police for subduing a man on Soy Street. Demonstrators continued to gather around Mong Kok shouting slogans, setting fire to debris and throwing debris towards the police throughout the night. A total of 230 people were arrested in the demonstrations across Hong Kong on the same day, with 19 people issued a fixed penalty ticket for violating the public gathering ban. [size=no report]

During the demonstration, two plainclothes police officers subdued a man who was reportedly smashing electronic devices in a drink shop at the mall. When a demonstrator approached the police waving an umbrella, the police officer fired pepper spray at the demonstrator and then a second time towards a group of journalists. 3 men were arrested. [size=no report]

NOTES: On July 19 2019, around 6100 Palestinians gathered at various locations along the border for this week's Return marches, throwing rocks and home-made crude explosives at soldiers. Dozens of Israeli flags were burned and Israeli forces fired at Palestinians attempting to sabotage the security fence. 122 Palestinians were injured, 57 by live bullets and 13 were hit directly by tear-gas canisters. Amongst the injured were 45 children, four women, three paramedics, and three journalists. Gaza's National Authority for Breaking the Siege urged members of the public to take part in Friday's demonstration. They erected barricades, burnt tires on the roads and clashed with the police and Gendarmerie forces who made use of tear gas and live ammunition. 2 people were killed, 8 were shot and injured, and a police officer was also injured. The demonstrators also reportedly threw stones at the journalists. At least 8 demonstrators were arrested including 3 women. The security force are also accused of attacking a private hospital during the repression. [size=at least 8]

SOURCE: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network

[size=no report]

SOURCE: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; Haiti Press Network
NOTES: On 13 February 2019, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, the building of the National TV (TNH) was vandalized and more than 8 vehicles in the parking lot were set on fire. The attack happened amid anti-government demonstrations across the country. [size=no report]

SOURCE: Haiti Press Network; Alterpresse; Loop News Haiti; RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network
NOTES: On 13 February 2019, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, thousands of rioters marched to the national palace to demonstrate against the current government. At least two people were killed during a clash between the rioters and the police. Rioters engaged in vandalism and a journalist was wounded while covering the event. 8 police officers were injured after demonstrators threw rocks at them at the level of Musseau, although one was reported injured by live ammunition. At the height of the national palace the rioters threw stones and the police threw tear gas to try to the rioters. Opposition senators participated in the demonstration. 2 fatalities. [size=thousands]

On June 7, 2019, in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, rioters, many of whom students and government employees, threw stones and erected burning barricades demonstrating against the high costs of living and insecurity, and demanded the resignation of the president. Some rioters threw stones and set fire to the car of the presidential spokesperson, while he fled. No injuries were reported. Also, a journalist was assaulted by a group of demonstrators who accused him of siding with the president. He was reportedly beaten several times. [size=no report]

On June 10, 2019, in Delmas 31 district in Port-au-Prince, a group of rioters on motorcycles site fire to three vehicles belonging to the Radio TV Ginen station. They reportedly left posters accusing the news agency of supporting the president. [size=no report]

On June 24, 2019, in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, a minivan of Radio Tele Metropole was pelted with stones while driving on a road, resulting in several broken windows. Other vehicles of the radio station were targeted a week before, amidst a series of attacks on media in the country. The station is accused of being pro-government. [size=no report]
On 24 June 2019, in Port-au-Prince, people participating in anti-government demonstrations threw rocks at a car belonging to a news outlet where two journalists were travelling. [size=no report]
On 24 June 2019, in Les Cayes, some people started a fire at the entrance of Radio Vwa peyizan Sid. The director condemned the action. [size=no report]

On 27 September 2019, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, people who were demonstrating to demand the resignation of the president of Haiti entered a radio station and after looting it, set it on fire. [size=no report]

On 30 September 2019, in Port-au-Prince - Carrefour, Ouest, a journalist was shot and injured during clashes between anti-government demonstrators and police. The rioters burned two vehicles and tried to set fire to the police sub-commissariat. To prevent this, the police threw tear gas and fired shots. [size=no report]

SOURCE: Le Nouvelliste; Haiti Standard; Loop News Haiti
NOTES: On 17 October 2019, in Leogane, Ouest, demonstrators attacked and set fire to public buildings and police vehicles. The premises of a radio station were also burned. The rioters demanded the resignation of the president of Haiti. One boy was shot and killed during a police intervention with teargas and gunfire. [size=no report]

On 18 October 2019, in Grand-Goave, Ouest, armed individuals set up a barricade and blocked the national highway number 2. A group of journalists who tried to pass were searched by the armed individuals who stole the money that they were carrying. Allegedly, the barricades are related to anti-government demonstrations. [size=no report]

On October 30, 2019, in Delmas, Port-au-Prince, a vehicle belonging to a broadcaster who had done an exclusive interview with the president, was attacked by people throwing stones. Anti-government demonstrators also blocked the entrance to the radio station in question. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Civilians (Haiti); Journalists (Haiti); Police Forces of Haiti (2017-)
NOTES: On 18 November 2019, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, a few hundred demonstrators participated in anti-government demonstrations, marching peacefully at first and then throwing rocks, bottles and Molotov cocktails at the Canadian embassy. Armed men fired shots at the demonstrators, injuring several people including a journalist and a police officer. Some demonstrators looted a shop and were arrested. [size=a few hundred]

On 23 February 2020 in Port-au-Prince, a radio station was vandalized; vehicles set on fire and windows broken. This happened during the ongoing police demonstration was but is unclear if the events are linked. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of Haiti (2017-); Civilians (Haiti); Journalists (Haiti)
NOTES: On 7 June 2020, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, police officers and political activists demonstrated for the release of a police officer who had been arrested, an increase in the salary of police officers and against the way in which the government managed the coronavirus in the country. The demonstrators demanded the departure of President Moise. Demonstrators erected barriers of burning tires. Police forces attempted to disperse the demonstrators with teargas. Two journalists were wounded by the police. [size=no report]

On 10 September 2020, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, high school students demonstrated over the lack of teachers in Haitian schools, as teachers have been striking for a month. Police vehicles were burned and the offices of Radio TV Caraibes was stoned. It is unclear whether these were perpetrated by schools students or university students who were demonstrating over the killing of President of the Bar Association that day. [size=no report]

SOURCE: RNDDH: National Human Rights Defense Network; AP; Le Nouvelliste; Haiti Standard
NOTES: On 20 January 2021, in Port-au-Prince, Ouest, demonstrators erected flaming barricades on the street and gunshots were heard through the day. Demonstrators demanded that President Moise steps down on 7 February 2021. Police forces dispersed the demonstration with tear gas and a woman was shot in the arm with live ammunition. Several journalists were injured with rubber bullets or beaten up. Five journalists and three demonstrators were wounded. [size=no repot]

On 20 January 2021, in Port-au-Prince - Delmas, Ouest, demonstrators erected flaming barricades on the street and threw rocks at passing cars. Demonstrators demanded that President Moise steps down on 7 February 2021. Police forces dispersed the demonstration with tear gas. Several journalists were injured with rubber bullets. [size=no report]

On 14 February 2021, in Port-au-Prince - Petionville, Ouest, thousands of people took to the streets to demand that the president steps down. A private car was set on fire. Police intervened with tear gas and rubber bullets after demonstrators tried to reach the building of the OAS - Organization of American States. At least three journalists were injured by rubber bullets, one of whom reportedly was shot 17 times. [size=thousands]

On 23 July 2021, in Cap-Haitien, Nord, hundreds of people gathered outside the private property where the funeral of President Moise took place, throwing stones at the Haitian authorities and journalists while they were leaving. The police intervened by using tear gas to disperse the crowd while gunfire rang out during the funeral. Rioters blocked several roads with barricades and burning vehicles, including the route through the airport. Clashes between the police and rioters took place. Bursts of automatic weapons were heard in different locations. [size=hundreds]

On 21 October 2021, in Jeremie, Grande-Anse, residents staged a demonstration against the increase in the prices of petroleum products and the scarcity in the market. The participants set fire to the premises of a radio station and attacked with stones the residence of a gasoline retailer. Clashes and violence were reported between the police and the rioters (unspecified). During the demonstration, two people were reportedly injured, one by a canister of tear gas and the other by a bullet in the foot. Bursts of automatic weapons were reported in different areas of the city. This event is related to a general strike, called by unionists, against crime and against the persistent scarcity of petroleum products on the national market. [size=no report]
On the second weekend of January 2018, a group of people that were participating in a demonstration attacked a journalist in Tegucigalpa, forcing her to leave.

On 20 August 2018, in Tegucigalpa (Distrito Central, Francisco Morazan), a group of students of several schools took part in a demonstration at the Suyapa Bulevar setting barricades and forcing bus passengers to abandon the vehicles. The participants demanded student bonds and discounts. Police officers intervened and clashed with the participants. During the demonstrations, students attacked with rocks some journalists and several were injured. Police used tear gas too. No fatalities were reported. [size=no report]

On 30 August 2018, in Tegucigalpa (Distrito Central, Francisco Morazan), street vendors attacked a group of national police officers who were carrying out an eviction in the historic sector of the capital because. The participants used sticks and stones. At least, 6 officers, three journalists, and one cameraman were injured. No fatalities were reported. [size=no report]

On 20 June 2019, in Tela Town (Tela, Atlantida), local inhabitants staged a demonstration and torched a cellar in front of the local police station. The police forces intervened, launching teargas canisters against the demonstrators and also against journalists present in the area. The reasons behind the demonstration are unclear, it could be in support to the Platform for the Defense of Public Health and Education or in support to the strike by heavy load truck drivers, or both. Also, teachers blocked some roads to demonstrate against the privatization of public education and health services. [size=no report]

On 7 September 2019, in Santa Rosa de Copan, Copan, unidentified men surrounded the house of a journalist, burnt his motorcycle and broke the windows of his car. The attack seems to be linked to his editorial line. In less than a week at least three journalists suffered attacks.

On 22 July 2021, in Villanueva, Cortes, bus and taxi drivers demonstrated and paralyzed transportation in different parts of the city to pressure the government into complying with demands. Taxi and bus drivers occupied several parts of the city and slowed down traffic as part of a national demonstration and to demand financial relief from the Honduran authorities, renewal of operating certificates, payment of reactivation bonus, refunds of the 2020 registration fees, among other requests. Police officers used tear gas to disperse the crowds and there were alleged confrontations between police. One journalist was injured after being hit by a rock. The drivers claimed that their demands are related to the economic crisis caused by the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]

A camera person of a local television channel, Anupam Das, was injured today in a clash that broke out during the Youth Congress's rally here at Singimari Bazar, Jalukbari, the constituency of BJP leader Himanta Biswa Sarma.

As per the injured journalist, at around 1 am, a photo-journalist had received a phone call from a medical college student calling them to come over to MKCG campus as they were holding a protest against alleged misbehavior of relatives of patients towards them. After getting this information the photo-journalist, accompanied by the reporter and another newsman reached the spot, and started taking photographs of students. Due to some reason the medical students got angry and manhandled them leading to the reporter receiving injuries.
Samajik Ekta Manch members held a protest and threw stones at the home of journalist Malini Subramaniam in Chhattisgarh, accusing her of being a Naxalite. They broke the windows in her house.
Lawyers linked to BJP attacked a journalist and threw stones at media personnel during court proceedings over JNU student union leader Kanhaiya Kumar.

On Feb 21, demonstrators and police clashed on NH-2 near Ballabgarh (Faridabad, Haryana); vehicles were damaged, journalists were beaten up by police. The Jats are demanding reservation under the OBC category.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: CPI(M): Communist Party of India (Marxist); Journalists (India)

Police said the journalists have alleged that they were specifically targeted after they tried to film Trinamool workers trying to 'rig' the elections.
In election related violence, media persons were allegedly attacked by Trinamool Congress supporters while they were asking questions to Left Front candidate Shyam Pandey.

A 10-hour bandh was called in Raha by various organizations to protest Mintu Deuri's death in a police firing yesterday. Several vehicles, including a van of a Guwahati-based private news channel, were damaged by the stone-pelting protesters. The district reporter of the news channel was also physically attacked by the protesters alleging that the news channel was not airing any news from Raha on the AIIMS issue. Hundreds of vehicles were stranded along the highway due to the road blockade at Raha Chariali.
Lawyers and reporters clashed over a disputed story regarding a lawyer.
Lawyers and reporters clashed for the second day over a disputed story regarding a lawyer.
Lawyers from Thiruvananthapuram district court attacked reporters, pelting beer bottles and stones at reporters. Several reporters were injured. Police were present but did not do anything.

SOURCE: Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, Srinagar
NOTES: On July 22, journalists were attacked by a mob and beaten while trying to take pictures of protest victims in Srinagar city (J&K).
On August 3, the news channel Samachar Plus claimed that two petrol bombs were hurled at its office in Dehradun city (Uttarakhand).

Clashes erupted between youth rioters and security forces in the Nowhatta, Zampi Kadal, and Kani Kadal areas of old city Srinagar with two senior photojournalists Farooq Javed and Waseem Andrabi injured during clashes as police used tear gas canisters to disperse rioters.

BJP hartal supporters blocked an ambulance at Cherthala in addition to attacking two cameramen of local television news channels. The BJP had called a 12-hour shutdown on Thursday to protest against the murder of its party worker.

Photojournalist R S Gopan of Malayala Manorama and freelance photographer Vishnu Prathap were attacked by BJP cadres while capturing the hartal at the Old Vegetable Market in Kottayam. The BJP had called a 12-hour shutdown on Thursday to protest against the murder of its party worker.

SOURCE: Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, Srinagar
NOTES: A photojournalist was wounded after being hit by a smoke shell fired by government forces (assumed police) during clashes between rioters and police at Bijbehara, Anantnag district on 16 Jan 2017. Rioters broke out following the death of 3 militants.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: BJP: Bharatiya Janata Party; Civilians (India); Journalists (India)

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: BJP: Bharatiya Janata Party; Civilians (India); Journalists (India)
NOTES: A protest march taken out by the Bharatiya Janata Party from Ambalamukku to Peroorkada, against the police action on its activists during a protest over the law academy issue, turned violent, leaving a few policemen, journalists, and party activists injured. The Peroorkada police have taken into custody 16 activists of the BJP, following the violence.

Clashes occurred between rioters and security forces after hundreds of demonstrators took to streets at main town Pulwama and shouted anti-forces and 'pro-freedom slogans. ASSOC_ACTOR_2: TMC: Trinamool Congress Party; Civilians (India); Journalists (India)
NOTES: A clash between Trinamool Congress and BJP supporters took place here. As many as 12 persons including BJP, Trinamool, two photo journalists and two police men were injured in the incident. At least three vehicles were damaged in the attack of the violent group.

Clashes occurred between demonstrators and security forces on 31 March 2017 after Friday prayers at several places in Srinagar in response to the Chadoora killings. A photojournalist was wounded in Srinagar's Rangreth area during the encounters.

A massive protest against by all student parties, who had joined hands to call for the PU Bandh to oppose fee hike at Punjab University campus turned violent on Tuesday, leaving over 60 students, cops and journalists injured 'Ai at least four of them critical. The police used force, water cannons and teargas and students resorted to stone-pelting. Fifty-two students were taken in police custody.

Shivraj Raju, reporter of Punjabi daily Ajit posted at Gidderbaha, on Saturday alleged that nearly a dozen Congressmen (including Charanjit Singh Dhillon, president of Truck Operators' Union of Gidderbaha) assaulted him at his office near Bharu chowk and forced him to drink alcohol and urine. He claimed that they made a video clip of the incident and also vandalised his office before fleeing. He sustained injuries on his chest and abdomen.

SOURCE: Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, Srinagar
NOTES: Students clashed with government forces (assumed police) on 24 Apr 2017 following the reopening of SP College in Lal Chowk area, Srinagar town, which had been closed due to protests. The police used teargas and pellet guns while rioters pelted stones. A youth and two photo journalists were wounded.

Government forces used teargas shells and batons to disperse demonstrators in the Bomai area near Sopore, after students of Government Higher Secondary School boycotted their classes in the morning and staged a protest against the arrest of students during the ongoing agitation. Several journalists were allegedly manhandled during the riots.

Over a dozen students from Degree College Kulgam and video journalist were wounded during clashes between rioters and police in Kulgam. Students pelted stones on police, who retaliated, some with pellet guns.

On June 15, in Singamari, two people were injured when police charged with tear gas and used batons after they were attacked by Gorkha activists with stones and petrol bombs as the police were returning from raiding GJM leader Bimal Gurung's office at Patlebas near Singhmari. A media van was also torched in the riot.
2 journalists were attacked by an unidentified group in Jorabat on 13 July 2017.

On September 11, hundreds of protesters set ablaze a liquor shop near the school where a 7 year old student was murdered at Bhondsi near Gurugaon, prompting the police to resort to lathicharge, in which many people, including journalists, were injured.
On Dec 4, five policemen and a photo journalist were injured in clashes with residents during an anti-encroachment drive in Jammu city.
On January 30, Hindu Yuva Vahini activists assaulted Muslim youths for harassing a Hindu girl in Meerut (assumed Meerut city, UP). They also assaulted a journalist covering the incident.

On February 21, between Mira Road and Andheri East railway station (Mumbai Suburban, Maharashtra), a journalist was assaulted by around eight to nine passengers inside a local train on the Western railway line for unknown reasons.

Supporters of the United Organization Co-ordination Committee bandh against the BTC's new land policy, burnt tyres across Kokrajhar district, Assam, on 6 March. Police arrested some demonstrators across the state. Bandh supporters also assaulted a journalist in Kokrajhar.

SOURCE: Hindustan Times; United News of India; Northlines
NOTES: Unidentified persons attacked journalists with sticks and blows in the Bhitindi area of Jammu tehsil/district on the afternoon of March 13. 2 attackers were arrested. The journalists were covering a story on Rohingya refugees; the journalists claimed at least some of the attackers were refugees themselves, or that some refugees joined in once the attack started.

SOURCE: Hindustan Times; United News of India; Early Times (India)
NOTES: Clashes occurred between hundreds of rioters in Naushera town and police forces on March 24. The rioters were gathering as part of an ongoing movement to demand district status. Police used 'mild force' to prevent the demonstration from moving forward; in response, rioters threw stones; police then used tear gas and lathi charged. 14-30 people--including at least 5 policemen, the District Deputy Commissioner, and a journalist--were injured. 6 were hospitalized. An ambulance, police cars, and private vehicles were also damaged.

On April 8, in Thoothukudi (Thoothukudi, TN), 13 DMDK functionaries assaulted journalists who had gone to cover Prematha's anti-Sterlite protest. Extent of injuries was not reported. The police arrested some of the DMDK workers after the assault.

Opponents of the Bharat Bandh called by groups opposed to caste-based reservations, attacked and injured a reporter in Muzaffarpur city, Bihar, on 10 April. The reporter was admitted to a hospital in a serious condition.

SOURCE: Sangai Express; United News of India
NOTES: On 17 April 2018, the house of the Shillong Times editor came under attack in Shillong (East Khasi Hills, Meghalaya). Two unidentified persons hurled a kerosene bomb. No one was injured and apart from a small blackened patch of wall, there was no damage to property. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack. [size=no report]

SOURCE: Kashmir Monitor; United News of India
NOTES: Clashes erupted between student rioters and police on Apr 19 in the Jamia Market in Shopian town. The students were rioting against the Asifa rape-and-murder case and pelted stones; the police responded with tear gas, lathi charge, and pellets. At least 10-15 students and 2 photojournalists were injured.

On May 3, in Malappuram (Malappuram, Kerala), RSS activists took out a demonstration and attacked a photographer working for a vernacular daily for taking pictures of their demonstration. The photographer was injured and sent to the hospital.
On 8 May, an unidentified group threw a crude bomb at the house of a journalist in Shillong city, Meghalaya. No casualties reported.
Nursing students staged a demonstration in Kolkata city, West Bengal, on 11 May, against the suicide of their colleague. Media members who went to cover the event were assaulted by students.

In an incident of Panchayat election violence, police used batons and tear gas to disperse a clash in Bhangar village, South 24 Parganas, West Bengal, on 14 May. Media vehicles were also set on fire and a camera destroyed by rioters.

In an incident of Panchayat election violence, 5 journalists were injured during violence after booth capturing by suspected TMC workers in Birpara town, Madarihat-Birpara, Alipurduar, West Bengal, on 14 May.
On May 17, suspected BJP supporters pelted stones and liquor bottles at the house of the Kamalpur Press Club Secretary in Kamalpur city (Dhalai, Tripura).

After which the man's family attacked and clashed with the MC staff and police with lathis. A journalist was injured during the clash.
A journalist was assaulted by BJP supporters in Kailashahar city, Unakoti, Tripura, on 29 June.
A journalist was severely assaulted by an unidentified group in Mohanpur town, West Tripura, Tripura, on 1 July. CPI(M) blamed BJP for the attack.

On 27 Aug, police fired smoke shells at rioters as they pelted stones at police vehicles in Pulwama district town (J&K). A journalist covering the clashes was injured. The rioting broke out following rumours that the Supreme Court was due to hear a petition challenging Article 35-A.

On September 17, a group of teachers attacked media persons at a government school in Piprakhoti village (East Champaran district, Bihar) injuring two of them. The reporters had arrived at the school after a teacher assaulted a student and left him unconscious.

On September 23, in Tharamangalam town (Salem, TN), Hindu temple officials clashed with journalists who were visiting the Kailasanathar temple after a dispute arose. The number of injuries was not reported.

On 8 Oct, voters assaulted photojournalists at the Bemina polling station in Srinagar city (J&K), amid concerns about potential ramifications of voting in the heavily boycotted local elections.
On 1 Nov, rioters targeted an ANI media van with rocks at Zugu village (Budgam, J&K) when they were in the area to report on an earlier clash between militants and state forces.

On December 7, in Lathi village in Pokaran Tehsil (Jaisalmer, Rajasthan), two rival groups clashed over polling. Several people, including a journalist, were injured in the clash.

NOTES: Assumed on December 15, local youths assembled on main roads in Newa village (Pulwama, J&K) and pelted stones at army vehicles and journalists who has come to report on events following a large civilian death toll during a CASO in Sirnoo village. No injuries reported.

SOURCE: AP; Xinhua; Al Jazeera; Deutsche Welle

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Lithuanian Nation and Justice Union; DP: Labour Party (Lithuania); Lithuanian Farmers and Greens Union; Government of Lithuania (2020-); Teachers (Lithuania)
SOURCE: LRT - Lietuvos Radijo Ir Televizijos; Delfi - Lithuanian News; TV3; Kauno Diena
NOTES: On 10 August 2021, approximately 5000 demonstrators gathered in front of the Lithuanian parliament in Vilnius to oppose planned restrictions for persons with no proven immunity to coronavirus or recent negative result from a PCR test. MPs and other politicians from the Lithuanian Nation and Justice Union and DP: Labour Party (Lithuania), as well as an MP from the Lithuanian Farmers and Greens Union spoke at the event. One of the organizers was a Lithuanian teacher known for taking part in right-wing themed demonstrations. The demonstration was permitted to last until 17:00, however several hundred participants refused to leave the area, blocking exits from the parliament buildings, where MPs were voting on the bill on coronavirus restrictions. Clashes later erupted with police, as rioters threw stones, smoke bombs and other objects at officers, while police responded with tear gas. 26 rioters were eventually detained by police, with 19 of them released from custody within a week. 10 police officers as well as a journalist for Lithuania's public broadcaster suffered injuries in the demonstration. [size=approximately 5000]
Radio station belonging to Ravalomanana set on fire

Students protested to demand payments for scholarships and equipment at the Polytechnical High School of Antananarivo. Police intervened and several were injured by stones, tear gas, and rubber bullets. At least one journalist was wounded in the crossfire.

Journalists in protest against the adoption of the Code of media communication. Strong deployment of security forces in Ankorondrano where barricates have been erected for steming what that the authorities claimed as unauthorized protests.

On 30 March 2020, a group of rickshaw pullers and youth demonstrated in Toamasina (Toamasina II, Atsinanana) against the lack of food provisions by the government during coronavirus lockdowns. The demonstrators clashed with police who intervened using tear gas. One journalist was stabbed and injured. [size=no report]

Shops were also looted during the handover. Police used teargas to disperse the crowd. [size=no report]

Hundreds protested the recent arrest of radio presenter Rasbath. Police fired tear gas and bullets, and protesters responded by throwing blunt objects; at least one protester killed and 11 injured.

NOTES: On 25 November 2021, in Fort-de-France, Fort-de-France, rioters set barricades on fire in support of the general strike called by unions against the health pass and the mandatory vaccination as measures to prevent the spread of coronavirus. The gate of the prefect's residence was set on fire by hooded individuals. Men on two motorcycles opened fire at four journalists while filming and taking pictures of the demonstration. The journalists managed to get into a vehicle, escaping unharmed. At least 2 police officers were injured. [size=no report]
Clashes between police and daily workers after they destroyed the local radio station.

SOURCE: La Jornada; Publimetro Mexico; El Norte
NOTES: On 16 August 2019, in Cuauhtemoc, Ciudad de Mexico, around 3500 women marched to reject femicides and any type of violence against women. On 23 August 2019, in Irapuato, Guanahuato, a group allegedly in favor of the municipal government, beat up a group of citizens demanding the increase in public transport fares. Journalists covering the event were also beaten. No injuries were reported. [size=no report]

On 25 November 2019, in Cuauhtemoc, Ciudad de Mexico, a group of women who had their faces covered destroyed public infrastructure, burned objects and attacked police officers who responded with fire extinguishers. The participants were part of the march that commemorates the international day to eliminate violence against women. A journalist and a woman were injured during this demonstration. [size=no report]

NOTES: On 14 February 2020, in Cuauhtemoc, Ciudad Mexico, a group of around 50 women gathered outside the Nacional Palace to complain about the cases of gender-based violence. On 19 February 2020, in Oaxaca, Oaxaca, a group of residents from Santa Cruz de Xoxocotlan broke into the Unitarian Agricultural Tribunals where a group of farmers atteneded an audience to recover their lands. On 8 March 2020, in Zacatecas, Zacatecas, around 2000 women marched to commemorate International Women's Day and to demand solutions to the increasing numbers of femicides. Some of the participants threw eggs and paint against public buildings. A male journalists who were covering the event were attacked by the participants. [size=around 2000]

SOURCE: Diario Contra Poder en Chiapas; Sintesis
NOTES: On 5 June 2020, in Puebla, Puebla, a group of merchants attacked a journalist who was recording in a market to show how the stores started to open despite that the coronavirus pandemic continues. [size=no report]

On 28 September 2020, in Tijuana, Baja California, around 200 women demonstrated demanding the legalization of abortion. The clash was triggered by the confiscating of municipal patrols, weapons and cell phones by the state police following the disappearance of over 28 thousand cartridges guarded by the municipal Police. SOURCE: 24 Horas (Mexico); Tiempo; Antena San Luis; Riodoce; Diario Contra Poder en Chiapas; La Prensa de Monclova; El Siglo de Durango
NOTES: On 8 March 2021, in Ciudad de Mexico - Cuauhtemoc, Distrito Federal, around 20,000 women held a demonstration on International Women's Day. Women gathered in Monumento a la Revolucion and marched until Zocalo. The demonstrators broke several glass windows along the way. A group of women demolished a section of the fence that was placed in front of the National Palace. They threw firecrackers, hammers, burning gasoline and Molotov bombs against the fence and set fire to the shields of the police. Police officers used tear gas to spread the crowd. 62 police officers and 16 people were injured. The police secured the rooftop to avoid drone overflights. Allegedly, four photojournalists were assaulted and arrested by the police as they covered the march. [size=around 20,000]

SOURCE: Entorno Informativo; La Silla Rota; La Prensa de Monclova; La Jornada
NOTES: On 1 April 2021, in Ciudad de Mexico - Coyoacan, Distrito Federal, around 18 hooded people gathered in Parque Hundido to demonstrate against several irregularities within the high schools of the National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM), including the lack of salary payment to teachers. The demonstrators also demanded justice for the killing of a Salvadoran woman killed in Tulum by the municipal police. The demonstrators later painted the walls and destroyed facilities of the University. They set part of the grass on fire and physically assaulted journalists who were trying to cover the event. One journalist was injured, his phone was stolen and his camera destroyed. The vehicles of the media were also damaged. [size=around 18]

On 12 April 2021, in Oaxaca de Juarez, Oaxaca, a group of people vandalized and physically assaulted journalists who were trying to cover the event near Macro square. The rioters, who claimed to be normalist students, arrived in public transportation vehicles that they had seized. They used buses and tires to blocks a street. On 16 May 2021, in Heroica Puebla de Zaragoza, Puebla, three journalists from 'MTP Noticias', 'Almanaque' and 'Diario Cambio' were beaten by members of the Morena party who supported the campaign of the candidate to the municipal presidency. The supporters of Morena attacked the journalist while they tried to record the complaints of a merchant whose stall was being removed to give space to a political rally. On 24 May 2021, in La Valla, Queretaro, about 20 people armed with metal pipes burst into a Morena rally and beat several members of the team of the candidate for governor of Queretaro and the candidate for mayor of San Juan del Rio. On 21 June 2021, in Toluca de Lerdo, Mexico, while the Chamber of Deputies was discussing a proposal for a draft decree to make the Commission on Gender Violence Alerts against Women for Feminicide and Disappearance a permanent Legislative Body, a group of hooded women demonstrated outside. On 5 July 2021, in Cancun, Quintana Roo, about 150 garbage collection workers demonstrated and blocked the avenues leading to the municipal palace with about 40 garbage trucks. The participants claim that they are being harassed by the municipal government and that the municipality is not paying as stipulated in the concession. The police intervened to put an end to the demonstration and the demonstrators responded by throwing rocks and Molotov cocktails. Eight rioters, and three police officers were injured. Around 26 October 2021 (week of), in Acapulco de Juarez, Guerrero, a group of people beat a female journalist of the newspaper 'El Sur' while she was interviewing the mayor of Acapulco. According to the report, the mayor was supporting the attackers. [size=no report]

On 18 November 2021, in Chilpancingo de los Bravo, Guerrero, farmers from Quechultenango, Jose Joaquin de Herrera, Atlixtac and Chilapa blocked the highway 'Autopista del Sol' around El Parador del Marques to demand that the state government attend paving works in their communities. The farmers also tried to take out the camera of a journalist after he tried to record the incident with the truck driver. [size=no report]

On 25 November 2021, in Villahermosa, Tabasco, women held a demonstration in front of the State Attorney General's Office (FGE) against violence against women in commemoration of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against women. The demonstration turned violent after journalists tried to take over pictures of the walls vandalized and painted by the women. A journalist was beaten and his work device was broken. The women stated they only want female journalist during their demonstrations. [size=no report]

On 6 December 2021, in Morelia, Michoacan de Ocampo, members of a teachers union blocked the Libramiento Sur in a demonstration to demand the provision of payments and job security. On August 19th, journalist Nicolae Josan was assaulted by a lone demonstrator, near a larger peaceful demonstration in Ialoveni.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: FNJ: Federation of Nepali Journalists; Journalists (Nepal)
NOTES: Nepalese journalists on Wednesday clashed with police as they picketed a government building in Kathmandu to demand improved security after the murder of a newspaper publisher. Around 100 media workers were chanting slogans and waving placards when the brief outbreak of violence took place. No injuries were reported and it is unsure who attacked who.

Riots continued today for the third day in a row in response to the alleged rape of a teenage girl by a local police officer. Marketplaces remained closed and vehicles did not ply the roads of the city. At least 35 demonstrators were injured in separate clashes with the police today, and more in previous days, including journalists.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: NSU: Nepal Student Union; Students (Nepal); Journalists (Nepal)
NOTES: NSU riots continued another day in the Capital, instigated by the arrest Nepal Students' Union (NSU) Vice President Bishnu Poudel for his alleged involvement in the attack on president of the CPN-UML-aligned All Nepal National Free Students Union (ANNFSU) Samik Badal and three other ANFSU leaders with sharp-edged weapons on Tri-Chandra College premises on April 12. Police clashed with students and journalists outside Trichandra College during which they also lobbed few tear gas shells and charged with batons to disperse the striking mob. Additionally, NSU cadres torched a police van at Ratnapark and vandalised four government vehicles. NSU with the same demand torched government cars in front of Pashupati Multiple College in Mitrapark, and staged demonstrations at Padma Kanya college.

The Nepali Congress-aligned NSU continued their protests outside the government colleges including Tri-Chandra and Pashupati College in the Capital on Tuesday, pressing for the release of their cadres, including NSU Vice President Bishnu Poudel. Police clashed with students in the Chabahil area, shooting tear gas to disperse the mob, which was throwing stones and torching vehicles. 6-14 people were injured, including some journalists, although they received only minor injuries. Traffic was also disrupted in the Capital as a result of the demonstrations.
