ASSOC_ACTOR_1: UCPN(M): Unified Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)
NOTES: A day after the UCPN(M) called off their nationwide strike, they declared they'd be starting a new form of agitation in protest of the ruling coalition. The areas around Singha Durbar, Kathmandu, were declared prohibited zones in view of the Maoists protest, however Maoist demonstrators ignored the decree. They beat up pedestrians and television cameramen, and set government vehicles on fire around the government complex on 9 May.

On Feb 21, following an incident with a water tanker accident, irate students vandalized the tanker and blocked the road from Chabahil to Gaushala. They also set on fire a vehicle of Nepal Electricity Authority and vandalized two public buses. Police had to bring the situation under control. Seventeen police personnel and eight students were injured in the clash. Riot police attacked at least seven photo journalists with batons when the latter were taking pictures of a clash between demonstrators and security personnel

A bandh called by Chhetri Samaj in Chitwan paralyzed the transport system in the district. Activists of Chhetri Samaj have staged demonstrations in various parts of Chitwan, demanding recognition as an indigenous group and a unique identity for the Chhetris in the new constitution. Journalists who had gone to report were assaulted by demonstrators.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: CBREP: Chure Bhawar Rastriya Ekta Party Nepal
NOTES: Normal life in the nation was affected owing to the bandh called by the Chure Bhawar Rastriya Ekta Party. The party called a two-day nation wide bandh, as part of its protest programmed ahead of a dire constitutional breakdown. The party cadres torched Kantipur Televisions van that was ferrying its staff at Balaju in Kathmandu. They also torched a bus of Nepal Yatayat at Lokanthali micro-bus at Maitidevi and a taxi at Basundhara.

At least 30 people-16 police personnel, 12 students and two journalists-were injured when students demanding a budget for the proposed Far-Western University clashed with police in Mahendranagar. Police detained 15 demonstrators during clashes that erupted after police baton-charged the demonstrators. The students have been agitating for a week demanding funds for the proposed regional varsity and the appointment of a chancellor.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: NEFIN: Nepal Federation of Indigenous Nationalities
NOTES: The Federation of Nepali Journalists has condemned the attack on the media by the bandh enforcers. The FNJ organized a corner meet at Maitighar Mandala in Kathmandu to protest the series of attacks on the press and intimidation by the NEFIN cadres. Many media vehicles were vandalized and journalists on duty manhandled at several places in the Kathmandu Valley.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: NEFIN: Nepal Federation of Indigenous Nationalities
NOTES: Bandh enforcers vandalized a vehicles carrying newspapers in Chitwan during the nationwide strike called by the Nepal Federation of Indigenous Nationalities (NEFIN) and Indigenous Nationalities Joint Struggle Committee (INJSC). The vehicle belonging to the Gorkhapatra Daily was vandalized and the district Secretary of Federation of Nepali Journalist was attacked.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: NEFIN: Nepal Federation of Indigenous Nationalities
NOTES: Journalists and press vehicles were attacked on the third day of Nepal bandh organized by the Nepal Federation of Indigenous Nationalities (NEFIN). A group of bandh enforcers manhandled a journalist of Mountain Television and vandalized a van belonging to the TV at Gatthaghar in Bhaktapur. The station manager of Star FM was also manhandled by demonstrators and his motorcycle vandalized.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: NEFIN: Nepal Federation of Indigenous Nationalities
NOTES: Nepal Federation of Indigenous Nationalities bandh supporters attacked a journalist in Palpa district, West, on 22 May.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: NEFIN: Nepal Federation of Indigenous Nationalities
NOTES: Attacks on journalists and media houses continued on the second day of the three-day nationwide shutdown enforced by Indigenous Nationalities Joint Struggle Committee in different parts of the country on 22 May. Irate shutdown enforcers attacked three journalists from Mountain Television and another of the Abhiyan Daily with iron rods while they were covering news at Gwarko Chowk in Lalitpur. One was seriously injured. Two other journalists reported being attacked by NEFIN activists in the district as well.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: NEFIN: Nepal Federation of Indigenous Nationalities
NOTES: Police held eight agitators in the capital on the third day of the general strike called by Nepal Federation of Indigenous Nationalities. A tourist shuttle was vandalized at Mahankal, in Bauddha, while a vehicle of tourism ministry was vandalized at Thecho in Lalitpur. A vehicle carrying copies of Nagarik daily was also vandalized by bandh enforcers in Kerkha, in Jhapa. A journalist was also beaten up in Palpa while two cops were injured in a clash with demonstrators in Makawanpur.

A journalist was manhandled by disqualified Maoist fighters during a bandh in Rapti region. The disgruntled fighters had put forward their demands and enforced the bandh. The journalist who was attacked sustained injuries and his motorbike was damaged.

A journalist was manhandled by disqualified Maoist fighters during a bandh in Rapti region on 2 Oct. The disgruntled fighters had put forward their demands and enforced the bandh. The journalist who was attacked sustained injuries and his motorbike was damaged.

A group of people identifying themselves as cadres of Shiv Sena Nepal stormed into the office of Nepal Republic Media and attacked four journalists and other staffers at Chinatown in Sundhara. Around 150 people aligned with the group picketed the publications while the attack was being carried out inside the office. Police took the situation under control later and rounded up some of the attackers.

Human Rights activists and journalists staged a sit-in at south gate of the Singha Durbar, Kathmandu, on Thursday morning to protest the PM's statement over arrests related to the murder of journalist Dekendra Thapa 8 years earlier. At the sit-in, a minor scuffle with the police occurred as the demonstrators tried to cross the restricted area.

Hundreds of YCL cadres wielding sticks and knives took out a rally and shouted slogans as they marched along Dailekh streets. They vandalized the office of Tesro Aankha Daily and warned the journalists that they too would soon meet Dekendra's fate. Earlier, they attacked the District Administration Office as well. This violence occurred on the same day as opposition protests against government interference in the murder investigation of journalist Dekendra Thapa.

UCPN (Maoist)-aligned Young Communist League ( YCL ) cadres attacked over half a dozen journalists at a programme in Banepa on Tuesday. The programme was participated by top UCPN (Maoist) leaders, including Chairman Puspa Kamal Dahal and Prime Minister Baburam Bhattarai. Police intervened before the situation got out of hand.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: ANNISU-R: All Nepal National Independent Students' Union-Revolutionary; Students (Nepal); Civilians (Nepal); Journalists (Nepal)
NOTES: Six students and a journalist were injured when police intervened in a clash between students from the ANNISU-R, CPN-Maoist (Baidya faction), and the Nepal Student Union in front of Birendra Campus, Bharatpur. Police had to charge with batons to take the situation under control.

A group of five CPN-M cadres boarded a Kantipur news vehicle in Palase, Bhaktapur, and set fire to it in Pagucha of Dhulikhel, while it was headed to Pachkal. There were no recorded injuries, but the vehicle and newspapers inside were completely destroyed.

A clash erupted between police and the kin of those who died in yesterday's bus accident, while the latter were picketing the Area Police Office in Tikapur, demanding compensation. At least four police personnel and a few demonstrators were injured. The clash erupted when the irate kin of the deceased started pelting stones at the police, who fired three rounds in the air and tear gas cells to bring the situation under control. Earlier, the kin had vandalized and set the office of the Tikapur Daily newspaper ablaze.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: UCPN(M): Unified Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist); CPN(M): Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)
NOTES: Shutdowns enforced on Monday by the UCPN (Maoist)-led 30-party alliance and the CPN-Maoist in several parts of the country turned violent: In Jhapa, banda organizers clashed with businesspersons at Chandragadhi. According to Partha Mandal, a local journalist, Madhesi Janadhikar Forum (Loktantrik) activist Ranjit Kumar Sinha was injured in the incident. Geoprecision code is 2 as this event was spread across the district.

Sanghiya Limbuwan Party Nepal activists vandalized a van belonging to Itahari-based Erina Television in Okhaldhunga for defying the banda. Their vehicle that reached the area to collect news was intercepted by banda enforcers. The van's windscreen was smashed in the process. (13/1)

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: UCPN(M): Unified Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist); Civilians (Nepal); Journalists (Nepal)
NOTES: The shutdown enforced by the UCPN (Maoist)-led 30-party alliance and the CPN-Maoist in various parts of the country on Tuesday: In Siraha, a person was injured after protesters clashed with police, with some journalists also being thrashed by the authority.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: UCPN(M): Unified Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)
NOTES: A vehicle (Ba 3 Cha 5850) carrying newspapers from Kantipur Publications Biratnagar regional office was set on fire by bandh enforcers in Mirchaiya of Siraha today (20/01).

The enforcers have looted Kantipur and The Kathmandu Post dailies from a vehicle at Babarmahal bridge this morning (20/01). A vehicle carrying Kantipur and The Kathmandu Post dailies has been torched at Mirchaiya in Siraha district. Some eight persons in four motorcycles stopped the vehicle and set it on fire after sprinkling petrol on it. The jeep (Ba 9 Cha 5850) has been completely destroyed in the arson.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: UCPN(M): Unified Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)
NOTES: In Ilam, bandh enforcers manhandled Sandakpur Daily journalist Tika Khadiwada and seized his motorbike key, said FNJ.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: UCPN(M): Unified Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)
NOTES: In another case, the bandh enforcers burned hundreds of copies of Kantipur daily in Babarmahal of the Capital, according to FNJ. A van (Ba 9 Cha 2933) belonging to Mountain Television was vandalised and journalists Srijana Kuinkel and Sharmila Thapa were abused in Babarmahal, FNJ added. Journalists Upendra Man Singh, Devaki Bista and Chhanya Chandra Bhandari from Associated Press, Himal news magazine and News Abhiyan respectively were also assaulted in Babarmahal this afternoon.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: UCPN(M): Unified Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)
NOTES: The bandh enforcers attacked Upendraman Singh, a photo journalist of Associated Press, while he was taking a photo of bandh enforcers vandalising the two-wheeler in New Baneshwor this morning.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: UCPN(M): Unified Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)
NOTES: A group of banda enforcers assaulted journalist Rishi Dhamala in Kathmandu on Sunday [16 August] when he was driving to his office. His car was also vandalized in the incident. A banda was called by the 33-party alliance led by the UCPN (M).

An unidentified group pelted stones and broke glasses of the building that houses the office of Annapurna Post [national newspaper] in Kathmandu on Wednesday evening [19 August]. Nobody was hurt in the incident.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: NEFIN: Nepal Federation of Indigenous Nationalities
NOTES: Activists of the Nepal Federation of Indigenous Nationalities vandalised a vehicle carrying the Annapurna Post daily in Duhabi on Sunday [23 August].
On Monday [31 August], the cadres of Samyukta Madhesi Morcha vandalized vehicles owned by Makalu Television and Himalaya Times in Biratnagar.

An unidentified group hurled a petrol bomb at the residence of photojournalist Ram Sarraf, who is affiliated with The Himalayan Times, in Birgunj of Parsa district on Sunday [13 September]. No one was injured in the incident.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: FNJ: Federation of Nepali Journalists; Journalists (Nepal)
NOTES: Agitating cadres of the United Democratic Madhesi Front (UDMF) vandalized and torched the building of Federation of Nepalese Journalists (FNJ), in Birgunj on Monday [21 September]. They also burnt copies of Annapurna Post, The Himalayan Times and Arthik Abhiyan at Chainpur, Bara along the Pathalaiya-Birgunj road section.

On 26 September, UDMF cadres staged protests at Madar customs point in Khairatoka, Siraha, and prohibited journalists to report the news. They also attacked a Post reporter Dev Narayan Sah who reached the site to prepare news reports on trade blockade.

With the death of one more person in Saptari on Sunday, the death toll in the clash between rioters and police has reached three in the district. According to eyewitness a local journalist of Rajbiraj Municipality-1 was fatally shot in the head by police. Other civilians were also injured.

Agitating United Democratic Madhesi Front (UDMF) cadres set ablaze a vehicle (Ba 13 Cha 495) belonging to Kantipur Publications at Parwanipur Chowk of Bara district on Sunday morning. It is learnt that UDMF cadres torched the vehicle after Kantipur daily published a special report about involvement of their leader in smuggling on Saturday. On Saturday, copies of the newspaper were burnt in the district to protest the report. UDMF cadres have been blaming the publications for publishing news against Madhes movement. Other articles online suggest Parsa district.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: ANTUF-R: All Nepal Trade Union Federation-Revolutionary
NOTES: Maoist trade union workers used violence to disrupt the distribution of The Himalayan Times (THT) and the Annapurna Post (AP), and clashed with police. The Maoists landed early morning at Sama Printers (printers of THT and AP) at Bhaisepati, Lalitpur, and forcibly took control of the vehicles loaded with newspapers. The police escorted the vehicles to the main distribution point at Bhugol Park and a clash ensued when the police attempted to recover the newspapers from the delivery boys, who had taken control of the distribution vehicles.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: FNJ: Federation of Nepali Journalists; Journalists (Nepal)
NOTES: On 3 March 2018, locals demonstrated by assaulting journalists affiliated to various media agencies, including members of Federation of Nepali Journalists, in Dunai locality (Dolpa district), accusing them of colluding with the municipality chief and not covering the news related to their demonstration against the decision to shift the administrative center of Thulibheri municipality. [size=no report]

On 18 July, two journalists sustained minor injuries after an attack by the police while they were covering the clashes between police and demonstrators in Jumla city, Karnali. The demonstrators had been demonstrating to support Dr. Govinda KC, who had been on hunger strike to demand reforms in the national medical education sector.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: NTD: Nepal Tarun Dal; Civilians (Nepal); Journalists (Nepal)
SOURCE: Targeted News Service; Kathmandu Post; Setopati
NOTES: On 21 July 2018, Tarun Dal members clashed with the police during a demonstration in Kathmandu city (Kathmandu). The activists were demonstrating in support of Dr. Govinda KC, who had been on hunger strike to demand reforms in the national medical education sector. Five journalists were attacked by the police during the clash and at least 12 NTD cadres and 14 police personnel were injured. [size=at least 12]

On 5 August 2018, students demonstrated, assaulted two journalists and vandalized hospital properties at Universal Medical College in Siddharthanagar city (Rupandehi) over the death of a student in the hospital. [size=no report]

On 2 October 2018, cadres of Nepal Student Union beat up a journalist and destroyed his camera in Kanchanpur district (location coded to Mahendranagar town, geo-precision 2) while enforcing a general strike demanding action against those responsible for rape and murder of a 13 year old girl in Kanchanpur. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: NSU: Nepal Student Union; Students (Nepal); Civilians (Nepal); Journalists (Nepal)
NOTES: On February 24, cadres of Nepal Student Union, the student wing of Nepali Congress, clashed outside the party office at Sanepa city (Lalitpur district, Bagmati). The clash resulted over a disagreement regarding setting age limit for union membership. A few students and a journalist were injured in the clash. [size=no report]

On June 20, an unidentified group assaulted a journalist from Salleri KhabarDotcom news agency, while he was collecting news in Lokanthali city (Bhaktapur district, Bagmati). The victim suffered injuries as a result of the incident. [size=no report]

On July 26, locals youths allegedly beat up a couple of journalists during a press conference in Shuklagandaki Municipality area (Tanahun district, Gandaki), expressing dissatisfaction over a news content that was published. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Journalists (Nepal); FNJ: Federation of Nepali Journalists
NOTES: As reported on August 22, an unknown group vandalized the office building of the Federation of Nepali Journalists- Baglung chapter- near Baglung area (Baglung district, Dhaualagiri). Further investigation of the incident is ongoing. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: FNJ: Federation of Nepali Journalists; Journalists (Nepal)
NOTES: On December 11, a group of 6 persons assaulted a journalist associated with the Federation of Nepali Journalist in Dharan city (Sunsari district), for arriving late to collect news. The FNJ issued a press release demanding action against the guilty. [size=6]

On 10 May 2020, a group of 4 people assaulted a journalist associated with Nepal Press Union in Awadhapur locality of Kalaiya Sub-Metropolitan City (Bara district), while the latter was returning home. The victim sustained injuries in the incident and is undergoing treatment at Kalaiya hospital. The reason for the assault was not reported. [size=4]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: NCP: Nepal Communist Party; Civilians (Nepal); Journalists (Nepal)
NOTES: On 11 February 2021, demonstrating youths including members of NCP clashed with the police at Baneshwor locality in Kathmandu city (Kathmandu district), following the arrest of, NCP leader Ram Kumari Jhankri. The incident occurred when the youths tried to break into a prohibited area in front of the parliament building, demanding the release of the NCP leader, arrested on the charge of engaging in anti-state activities. During the incident police forces beat and injured a journalist, who was covering the demonstration. [size=no report]

On 24 January 2021, dozens of people staged a demonstration in Tilburg to denounce the coronavirus lockdown measures of the Dutch government, in particular the curfew that was imposed since the night before. The demonstration turned violent when rioters started to throw fireworks, burn cars and destroy shop facades. Two camermen who were filming were pelted with stones and forced to flee. Police forces intervened and arrested 19 people. [size=dozens]

On 25 January 2021, dozens of people staged riots in Haarlem as a reaction to the curfew that was imposed since that week as a protective measure against the spread of the coronavirus. Intervening police forces and journalists were targeted with stones. 14 people were arrested. [size=dozens]

On 31 January 2021, around 600 people 'spontaneously' assembled to demonstrate against the coronavirus protection measures of the Dutch government at the Museumplein in Amsterdam. As demonstrations at the Museumplein were prohibited due to recent violent demonstations, a large police force was present to disperse demonstrators. The demonstrators responded by throwing projectiles. Four arrests were made around Museumplein, including of a demonstrator who kicked a journalist. [size=around 600]

On 19 April 2021, a journalist and a his girlfriend were attacked by an angry mob in Lunteren when filming a car fire while passing by. Their car was assaulted with baseball bats and a forklift and a shovel pushed it into a ditch for no apparent reason. The two people were injured. [size=no report]

On 7 May 2021, at night, journalists were violently attacked by a group of football supporters of De Graafschap Doetinchem while they were reporting on the return of the De Graafschap team after their defeat in Amsterdam. [size=no report]

On 22 February 2019, in Managua, rioters attacked four journalists that were covering a judicial process against a political prisoner and journalist. The rioters threw garbage to the journalists, stole a cell phone from one of them and tried to steal a camera. The police was present but did not intervene. [size=no report]

On 22th November 2019, in Masaya, a New York Times journalist was attacked by rioters as she was covering a hunger strike going on inside a Catholic church that turned into a siege with police cutting off supplies or people into it. She declared the attacks came by supporters of the regime of President Ortega, and that police did nothing to protect her. [size=no report]

On 27th December 2019 in Leon (Leon), 17 rioters arrived on motorcycles and broke the security camera and damaged the installations of Dario Radio. The radio is known for its political opposition against the regime of President Ortega and has suffered other attacks throughout 2019. [size=17]

On 11 May 2021, in Managua, Managua, a group of 15 people attacked two reporters and took their phone at a market. The reporters had arrived to cover a story when they were followed and beaten by the group of Ortega supporters. [size=15]

On 25 February 2021, hundreds of demonstrators attempted to erect barricades in Niamey (Ville de Niamey, Niamey). Security forces dispersed the demonstrators. The demonstrators vandalized several homes and vandalized and burned the house of a prominent journalist. The demonstration was held in the context of the post-presidential election runoff demonstrations in Niger. [size=hundreds]

Media worker John Musa was killed in Maiduguri, Borno state, on 28 April 1999, when policemen clashed with protesting Borno state civil servants who are on strike to press for a N3,000 (US$32) minimum wage. Musa was a member of the circulation staff of the Jos-based Plateau state publishing company which publishes the 'Standard' newspaper.
On 20 November 2002, Muslim rioters burned down a newspaper office in Kaduna city (Kaduna) after they printed an unfavorable article. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: ANPP: All Nigeria People's Party; PDP: People's Democratic Party
NOTES: About 20 persons - identified as ECOMOG members - have been arrested by the police in connection with the destruction of properties worth millions of naira at Banki town in Bama local government area. Police sources confirmed that five people, including two reporters of the Nigeria Television Authority (NTA), sustained injuries as a result of the crisis.

Two Police officers and two journalists with Vanguard newspapers narrowly escaped death, during the evening hours at Shabu village, Nasarawa State when a group of youths, protesting against the death of their colleagues, held them hostage for hours. The demonstration began against speed-breakers along a nearby highway - the protesters barricaded the road with objects and lit fires.
A reporter and his photographer were attacked and beaten by angry youths in Rumu-Osi. The details of the attack were not clear.
A group violently protest arrests by Federal Road Safety Commission by destroying several of their vehicles and attacking reporters covering the event along the Abuja-Lokoja road.

Police clash with Okada Riders protesting the seizure and impounding of their motorbikes in the Ajao, Ikeja area of Lagos metropolis. Except for a reporter who was attacked by police for covering the event, there were no reported injuries by the warring sides.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: IPOB: Indigenous Peoples of Biafra; Journalists (Nigeria)
NOTES: IPOB stages a protest, blocking roads, in Onitsha over the continued detention of their leader, a notable radio personality. One protester was feared dead for unknown reason (fatality unconfirmed).

5,000 pro-Biafran protesters (affiliation not known, likely MASSOB and/or IPOB) blocked the Aba/Port Harcourt express way, calling for the release of a radio commentator. Police open fire on the group with live bullets and tear gas, one confirmed death, plus injures.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: RATAWU: Radio and Television Workers Union; Journalists (Nigeria)
NOTES: Workers of RATAWU attempt to forcibly shut down a broadcast station of Radio Bayelsa over non-payment of salaries, but are dispersed by police and well as the Information Commissioner who was present.

Members of the Ijaw Youth Council invade a radio station in an effort to interrupt a live broadcast over a disagreement over organizational leadership. The attackers stole items at the station and assaulted employees.
Federal University of Technology workers protest against the actions of their Vice Chancellor, attack journalists covering the event.
Demonstrators protest the death and alleged murder of Senator Isiaka Adeleke. The protesters assaulted a TV news correspondent during the demonstration, leading to a presenter being hospitalised.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: IPOB: Indigenous Peoples of Biafra; Journalists (Nigeria)
NOTES: Members of IBOP disrupt an ECA meeting in Enugu. The members stoned cars, chased journalists, and blocked roads.

16 January. Irate youth in Dere set a bus on fire that transported journalists to a meeting with chiefs and community leaders in the area. The youth felt increasingly sidelined and started to resist the meeting.
18 March. Demonstrators against non-working electricity supply of Kwara communities in Ilorin barricaded roads and destroyed equipment of journalists.[size=no report]
27 April. A group of journalists were attacked and harassed by angy voters during supplementary elections in Lagos. Police forces rescued the journalists.
08 July. APC supporters of Kogi Governor Bello stormed the parties HQ in Abuja to prevent an anti-Bello protest. Journalists were attacked by the APC demonstrators. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: NASU: Non-Academic Staff Union; SSANU: Senior Staff Association of Nigerian Universities; Labour Group (Nigeria); Teachers (Nigeria)
NOTES: On 22 January 2020, members of the NASU and SSANU demonstrated over the non-payment of their allowances at the University of Oye-Ekiti (Oye LGA, Ekiti). The demonstrators attacked journalists that covered the event. [size=no report]
On 28 February 2020 (or around), a PDP chairmanship candidate in the forthcoming LGA elections and his supporters attacked a journalist in Abuja (Abuja LGA, FCT). [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: APC: All Progressives Congress; NUJ: Nigerian Union of Journalists; Journalists (Nigeria)
SOURCE: Blueprint; Daily Post (Nigeria); Vanguard (Nigeria); Nigeria Punch; Sun (Nigeria); Daily Independent (Nigeria)
NOTES: On 16 July 2020, a group of APC supporters attacked a press conference of a rival APC faction at the NUJ office in Bauchi (Bauchi LGA, Bauchi). Journalists were injured. [size=no report]

On 19 September 2020, persons affiliated with the APC assaulted journalists at Ward 10 in the Iyamho area of Uzairue (Etsako West LGA, Edo) for allegedly taking pictures and videos of voter inducement. [size=no report]

On 26 February 2021, angry youth and women demonstrators vandalized vehicles conveying journalists and critically injured one journalist in Jangebe (Talata Mafara LGA, Zamfara) over the abduction of over 300 schoolgirls from their community. Angry parents also vandalized the school buildings of the Government Girls Secondary School in the same area. [size=no report]

On 5 June 2021, some members of The Synagogue attacked journalists at the church headquarters in Ikotun (Alimosho LGA, Lagos) over the media's past coverage of the church and its founder. No reported fatalities. [size=no report]

On 31 July 2021, 12 rioters invaded a radio station at Moniya (Akinyele LGA, Oyo state). The riot was as a result of the killing of one person the previous day at Shasha by local vigilante whose office was located on the premises of the radio station. One person was killed, many were wounded and properties were destroyed. [size= 12]

On 24 August 2021, a lawmaker and journalists were attacked by a mob numbering up to fifty at a meeting in Aba (Aba South, Abia). The attack was reportedly as a result of the lawmaker's demand for the roads in his constituency to be fixed by the state government. [size=up to fifty]
On 7 September 2021, a journalist was stoned and killed by unknown individuals in Okene (Okene, Kogi). The reason of the attack is unknown/not reported. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: IPOB: Indigenous Peoples of Biafra; Lawyers (Nigeria)
NOTES: On 21 October 2021, over one hundred lawyers and supporters of IPOB leader demonstrated in Abuja (Abuja Municipal, FCT ) over the closure of the court by security operatives, barring them from attending the hearing or accessing other parts of the court. A group of demonstrators ttacked the former presidential aspirant, and publisher of a journal, Omoyele Sowore, while he tried to gain entry to the hearing. The group also threw petrol bombs against the court premises. [size=over 100]

'PML-N workers' attacked journalists shortly after the beginning of a press conference held by MNA Hanif Abbasi related to the attack on Sheikh Rasheed Ahmad. It is not clear why they were attacked, but several journalists were injured.
Students attempted to stop a TV anchor from entering the Islamia College of Peshawar to deliver a controversial lecture perceived as being in support of 'terrorists', leading to a clash.

Journalists injured by doctors as well as at least 20 of their colleagues at Jinnah Hospital demonstrated against the doctors who injured them. In response, one of the leading doctors allegedly went on the intercom to call doctors to attack the journalists, leading to a clash where around 40 doctors attacked the journalists.

After a clash between doctors and journalists at Jinnah Hospital, about 100 doctors and paramedical staff ransacked the Saher Cable Network and injured 10 staff members of the network 'for not blocking their service' in relation to the violence between doctors and journalists at Jinnah Hospital.
Doctors 'severely tortured and thrashed' journalists while they were attempting to report at the Civic Hospital in Gujranwala.
An examination monitoring team, including media personnel, and an official from the BSEK school board were beaten up by school staff and 'miscreants' in Shah Faisal Town of Karachi.

In Karachi, the Sindh National Party (SNP) leaders and workers staged a sit-in outside the building of Jang group. Some of the activists attacked the offices of the Jang Group and Geo Television and snatched weapons from security guards and resorted to aerial firing. The police fired bullets in the air, hurled teargas shells and resorted to baton charge to disperse the activists.

In Timergara, All Primary Teachers Association (APTA) went on a riot, torched copies of national dailies, injuring three journalists. The riot had been conducted in conjunction with the Sindh wide protests over rights of teachers. The police had to interfere to stop the riot.

In Timergara, members of the All Primary Teachers Association (APTA) rioted and torched copies of national dailies, injuring three journalists. The riot had been conducted in conjunction with the Sindh wide protests over rights of teachers. The police had to interfere to stop the riot.
Lawyers attacked media men in Lahore on 2 Oct 2010 during a protest against the police.

The family of the victims, after three men were murdered, staged protest at G. T. Road near Tarnol and set tyres and wastage on fire. The protesters were demanding the immediate arrest of the killers.

In Chakwal, protesters blocked the Chakwal-Mianwali, Talagang-Rawalpindi and Talagang-Sargodha roads, burning tyres and chanting slogans against the government. They demanded an immediate end to the long and unscheduled loadshedding.
Over a dozen journalists and policemen were assaulted as rioters during Ishq-e-Rasool protests besieged Hyderabad Press Club.

On October 1st, around 100 PML-N activists assaulted a man and 2 journalists after they tried to stop them from entering the Muzaffarabad Press Club. Earlier, around 2 dozen PML-N activists had staged a demonstration outside the locked Press Club and torched copies of newspapers which had published a news item about their party president. The civilians were not seriously wounded.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: YDA: Young Doctors Association; Health Workers (Pakistan)
NOTES: Members of the YDA held a demonstration at a hospital in Lahore that turned violent when the doctors attacked the Medical Superintendent and several journalists. The YDA announced a strike until their demands for the removal of the MS were met.
The Long March of Dr. Qadri continued, with female journalists covering the protest allegedly being harassed by demonstrators.
Rioters injured 4 cameramen who were covering a religious party's public meeting in Hyderabad.
Workers of PTI allegedly scuffled with reporters and cameramen during a protest against the alleged rigging in by-elections, at Chairing Cross. They injured a cameraman by beating him up.
After the clash of the religious group in which leader of ASWJ died a mob ransacked the local office of Sindhi TV channel and injured its reporter.
The offices of a media group came under attack causing injury to a security guard and damaging few parked vehicles. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack.

A large number of Journalists staged a sit in outside the Jinnah bagh chowk against the killing of three workers of Express News channel in Karachi. Rally started from Larkana Press Club and reached at Jinnah Bagh chowk where protesting journalists staged sit in blocked road and set the tyres on fire for arresting the involved accused behind attack.
On February 17, crude bombs were thrown at offices of Aaj television and at Waqt TV in Karachi city (Sindh) but no injuries were reported.
A van owned by the Jang group of newspapers was attacked and burned in Lahore.
A van owned by the Jang group of newspapers was attacked and burned on Murree Road.
A vehicle carrying copies of the Daily Jang newspaper was set on fire in the Hassan Square area of the city by unidentified men on 3 June 2014 in Karachi. No injuries occurred.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: PAT: Pakistan Awami Tehreek; PTI: Pakistan Tehreek-i-Insaf
NOTES: A crowd of PTI and PAT activists gathered outside the Geo News office and attacked it with stones. Workers inside were able to escape unharmed. No injuries were reported.

Rioters once again attacked the Geo News office in Islamabad. A group of people participating in the sit-ins gathered outside the office and pelted it with stones. No casualties or injuries were reported.
PTI rioters clashed with female journalists, pelting stones and bottles at them during PTI's 'Shutdown to Rebuild' national effort
On 31 Dec, demonstartions by the 16/12 Action forum turned violent all over Peshwar district (KP) with rioters clashing with police and media personnel.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: IJT: Islami Jamiat-e-Talaba; Students (Pakistan); Civilians (Pakistan); Journalists (Pakistan)
NOTES: IJT protestors clashed with police outside the French Embassy, tear gas and rubber bullets were used by the police who were responding to violence such as rock throwing from the protestors, a Pakistani journalist working for a French news agency was also injured in the protests with a bullet to the lung.

On 26 Aug, student staged a demonstration in Karachi city (Sindh) against the increase in tuition fees for select students. The demonstration turned violent as students and media persons who where at the site to record the event clashed with police and university authorities.
In Hyderabad a TV channel van was also attacked by protesters angry over the pre-dawn execution of Mumtaz Qadri, the killer of Punjab governor Salman Taseer.

During a protest by the Sunni Tehreek and JUP outside the Hyderabad press club over media censorship, some angry protesters engaged in an arson attack occurred which injured some journalists and a boy who had been protesting. He later died in hospital. Two other protesters were also seriously injured.

The protest against the execution of Mumtaz Qadri was marred by violence when participants in a rally 'clashed' with police and damaged vans of some media houses meant for coverage here on Friday. The rally had been taken out by the Pakistan Sunni Tehreek from Bhati Chowk up to Charing Cross on The Mall after Friday prayer

Two journalists were injured when activists of the Anjuman Talaba Islam (ATI) subjected them to physical violence while attacking the Karachi Press Club with petrol bombs and resorting to arson on Sunday evening. The assailants tried to enter the club and set vehicles on fire.

Activists of the Sunni Tehreek manhandled journalists in Islamabad as they gathered outside Parliament House at the Red Zone to protest against the hanging of Mumtaz Qadri. Many journalists, including cameramen, were injured.

The leaders of former Karachi mayor Mustafa Kamal's fledgling Pak Sarzameen Party (PSP) received a hostile reception in Mirpurkhas on Thursday as their motorcade was attacked in over half a dozen locations in the district. At least 10 persons, including two reporters, were injured after locals pelted the PSP with stones and eggs.

Reported Apr.30: During a protest held against alleged corruption in a school in Bahawalnagar, its headmaster called the police saying that the school has been attacked by terrorists at Chak 112/M in order to disrupt it. When journalists attempted to get the headmaster to explain his actions, the headmaster and some teachers mandhandled them and allegedly forcibly confined them and took one of their cameras.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: WAPDA: Water and Power Development Authority
NOTES: WAPDA officials tortured a local journalist and stopped him from covering the protest against the WAPDA officials.

The activists of PTI Tuesday attacked the reporting team and DSNG of Geo TV near Burhan in the territorial limits of the Punjab province. The activists tortured the reporting team and tried to set the DSNG on fire. Meanwhile, PTI MPA Arif Yousuf intervened and stopped the party activists from doing such act. The Geo reporting team was attacked when it was covering the protest.
Women from Karak blocked the Indus highway for 7 hours over low gas pressure. They also burned tires and scuffled with journalists who tried to pass through the area.
On February 4, some influential men attacked the Tando Mir Ali press club and harassed the journalists there over their reporting.
SEPCO employees allegedly assaulted a journalist and broke his camera after he inquired over a fallen high tension wire.
At least five journalists including three cameramen were injured on Monday after men alleged to be Pak Sarzameen Party (PSP) workers attacked them at Sukkur Press Club during a protest.

On Sep 13, 4 journalists clashed with doctors and paramedics at the taluka hospital in Thul town (Jacobabad, Sindh) after the journalists manhandled a storekeeper who refused to pay them extortion money. Several people suffered minor injuries.

On November 23, journalists and media workers along with the support from PPP leaders demonstrated, burned tires and effigies at Charing Cross in Data Gunj Buksh town (Lahore, Punjab) against alleged firing of journalists and staffs by media houses and the government's support for such actions.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: PPP: Pakistan Peoples Party; Civilians (Pakistan); Journalists (Pakistan)
NOTES: On March 20, police baton charged to disperse PPP activists who allegedly pelted stones at the police during a demonstration outside the NAB office in Islamabad city (Islamabad, Federal Capital Territory). At least six police personnel and one news cameraman were reported injured while more than 60 PPP activists were reportedly arrested. [size=thousands]
As reported on May 11, District Accounts Officer and his supporters assaulted journalists and attempted to seize their cameras in Kotri town (Jamshoro, Sindh).
On June 20, a mob of people vandalized the office and set fire to the furnitures of Awami Press Club Malir in Malir town (Karachi, Sindh). [size=no report]

As reported on November 2, a crowd of members of JUI-F and AI, demonstrated, barred female journalists from reporting about the 'Azadi March' demonstration camp and baton charged motorcycle riders to clear their sit-in camp area at Peshawar Mor in Islamabad city (Islamabad, Federal Capital Territory) when female journalists attempted to report on the ongoing 'Azadi March' demonstrations. [size=crowd]

On November 18, AI and JUI-F activists attacked, assaulted and held hostage journalists during the ongoing sit-in on GT Road in Hakimabad locality of Nowshera city (Nowshera, KP) as part of 'Plan B' of the JUI-F led 'Azadi March' campaign against the federal government demanding the resignation of Prime Minister Imran Khan and early elections. The incident occurred when the journalists were covering the sit-in. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of Pakistan (2018-); Civilians (Pakistan); Labour Group (Pakistan); Health Workers (Pakistan); Journalists (Pakistan)
NOTES: On December 11, police used tear gas and baton charged large number of lawyers after they vandalized parked cars, medical equipments, windows and doors of wards and operation theatres, assaulted hospital staffs, doctors, nurses, journalists and Punjab Information Minister and pelted stone at the police and set a police mobile on fire at Punjab Institute of Cardiology (PIC) in Data Gunj Buksh town (Lahore, Punjab) during a demonstration outside PIC against a video showing a doctor roasting lawyers about an alleged incident of assault on lawyers by doctors. The violence reportedly began after the demonstrating lawyers blocked entry and exit points of the hospital, which led to a scuffle between hospital staff and lawyers. Some of the demonstrators allegedly fired gunshots. Dozens of lawyers were reportedly arrested after the incident while at least three patients lost their lives after patients in emergency and intensive care were left unattended by doctors and nurses feeling the violence. [size=large]

On 12 December 2020, rioters attacked and injured an anchorperson in Lahore city (Lahore, Punjab). Police claimed it was an act of personal enmity but the journalist claims otherwise. [size=no report]

On 21 February 2021, people demonstrated, assaulted staff and vandalized offices of Geo and Jang Media Groups central offices in Karachi city (Karachi City, Sindh), over an edited snippet from a television program. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: TLP: Tehreek-e-Labbaik Pakistan; Muslim Group (Pakistan); Civilians (Pakistan); Journalists (Pakistan)
NOTES: On 14 April 2021, activitst of TLP demonstrated and clashed with the police in Karol Ghatti area of Lahore city (Lahore, Punjab) against the arrest of their chief. Police personnel allegedly beat and injured photojournalists when they were covering the TLP demonstrations. [size=no report]

On 5 July 2021, students demonstrated and later pelted stones at the police outside the Higher Education Commission (HEC) headquarters in Sector H-9 in Islamabad city (Islamabad, FCT), against holding in person exams during the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. In retaliation police baton charged demonstrators also injuring a journalist, who was covering the demonstration. [size=no report]

On 27 February 2021, in Panama City, Panama, people staged a demonstration in front of the National Secretary for Children, Youth and Families against the abuse of minors in shelters. Demonstrators threw bottles and stones and tried to remove the fences surrounding them. Police officers intervened with tear gas. One journalist was hit with tear gas and participants were arrested. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: ANR-PC: National Republican Association - Colorado Party
NOTES: On 22 April 2018, in Luque, Central, dozens of people affiliated to the former senator Oscar Gonzalez Daher (ANR), also known as 'hurreros,' beat up journalists that tried to get close to him. The event happened when the former senator was entering a school to vote for the general elections of 2018. [size=dozens]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: ANR-PC: National Republican Association - Colorado Party
NOTES: On 9 November 2018, in Ciudad del Este, Ciudad del Este, supporters of the Zacarias family (ANR politicians) attacked a journalist/photographer. He was pushed and fall to the ground. The group also threatened him with a knife. The journalist was taking photographs during a meeting of the supporters (hurreros) at the Square 'plaza de la paz' in Ciudad del Este. [size=no report]

On 5 March 2021, in Asuncion (Asuncion), more than 5,000 people gathered near the National Congress asking for the resignation of government authorities, including the President Mario Abdo Benitez, claiming they were working against the interests of the Paraguayan people. They also demonstrated against the government's handling of the coronavirus pandemic, which led to the collapse of hospitals due to lack of supplies and medicines. Clashes were reported between the police and the demonstrators and State buildings were damaged. The police used a water cannon, tear gas and rubber bullets. Many people were injured, including demonstrators, police officers and journalists. A demonstrator was stabbed to death while leaving the area, allegedly by criminals. 1 fatality. [size=more than 5,000]

On 8 March 2021, in Asuncion (Asuncion), for the fourth consecutive day, a group gathered near the National Republican Association (ANR) headquarters and damaged the car of a TV channel, while asking for the resignation of government authorities, including the President Mario Abdo Benitez, claiming they were working against the interests of the Paraguayan people. They also demonstrated against the government's handling of the coronavirus pandemic, which led to the collapse of hospitals due to lack of supplies and medicines. Part of this group gathered in front of former President Horacio Cartes' house as well, claiming he attacks democracy and the rule of law in Paraguay. In Uruguaya square, a group threw rocks at the police, who responded by using a water cannon, tear gas and rubber bullets. Between 16 to 18 people were arrested. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Civilians (Paraguay); ANR-PC: National Republican Association - Colorado Party; Journalists (Paraguay)
NOTES: On 17 March 2021, in Asuncion (Asuncion), for the thirteenth consecutive day, a group gathered near the National Congress, asking for the resignation of government authorities, including President Mario Abdo Benitez, claiming they were working against the interests of the Paraguayan people. Besides, another group gathered in front of the President's residence. In addition, demonstrators broke into the National Republican Association (ANR) building, which was set on fire, an off-duty police officer shot towards them. Rioters reacted by throwing bombs and stones at police officers. 27 people were arrested and others were injured, including the report of a person who was tortured by officers. A journalist was also attacked by one rioter. [size=no report]

On 22 March 2018, the peaceful demonstrations from citizens turned into aggressive demonstrations in Lima, especially against a journalist that was attacked by stones and bottles. The demo was initially against the political crisis that the country was facing with the resignation of Pedro Pablo Kuczynski from the presidency.

On 27 July 2018, in Plaza San Martin, Lima, demonstrations were held against corruption, regarding a recording in which judges are heard negotiating to favor close people in their decisions, turned into street-fighting against police forces. The police used tear gas and a group of vandals were arrested during the events. Additionally, a journalist was injured by a rock that was thrown by the rioters. This was the third consecutive day of demonstrations.

On August 9 2019, in Lima - Lima District, Lima Province, Keiko Fujimori sympathizers gathered outside Judicial Power in the sector to demand celerity in the decision of releasing the politician from prison or not. During the demonstration a group of people attacked Journalists that were trying to cover the event. [size=no report]

On 29 June 2020, in Lima-San Juan de Miraflores, Lima Province, a journalist and a cameraman were attacked with stones by a group of men who were breaking coronavirus quarantine rules and playing soccer. The victims were covering the events, as residents had alerted a media group about the people breaking quarantine. [size=no report]

On 25 October 2020, in Huanta, Ayacucho, local police officers (Serenos) were attacked by informal merchants in the city center. They were carrying out an operation to enforce social distancing measures to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. Merchants claimed they wanted to continue selling their products. An unknown number of officers and journalists covering the operation were injured. [size=no report]

On 14 November 2020, in Lima-Lima District, Lima Province, hundreds of citizens marched through Abancay avenue towards the Congress offices as a demonstration for the fifth consecutive day, against the Congress decision of ousting President Martin Vizcarra (no party) following an impeachment vote, and against the swearing-in of Manuel Merino (AP party). Police forces stopped them from advancing with tear gas and pellets, and the demonstrators threw paint, rocks and other objects. 6 people and 1 journalist were reported injured. 2 demonstrators were shot and killed during the demonstration. [size=hundreds]

On 14 July 2021, in Lima - Lima District, Lima Province, a group of Popular Force (FP) supporters and members of The Resistance, a group that supports FP, forcibly opened the gates of Chabuca Granda square to enter the Palacio de Gobierno. They demanded respect to their votes and claimed there was fraud in the presidential elections. Police forces used tear gas to disperse them. During the demonstration, they attacked two journalists. Dozens of supporters of the FP also demonstrated outside the offices of the Judicial Power. [size=dozens]

On 8 May 2020, activists, mostly businessmen, gathered in Warsaw, demonstrating against measures imposed by the government because of the current coronavirus pandemic. Law enforcers later dispersed the demonstration and detained several dozen of them; few policemen were reportedly injured during the action. [size=no report]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Women's Strike; Women (Poland); SLD: Democratic Left Alliance; Journalists (Poland)
SOURCE: Rzecz Pospolita; RMF24; WiadomosciWp; Polsat News; Tvn24; Onet
NOTES: On 18 November 2020, several thousand activists, mostly women and including SLD members, demonstrated in Warsaw with the motto 'Blockade of the Sejm' against restrictions of abortions in Poland. The event was coordinated by the Women's Strike. The demonstration path was several times blocked by the police. As activists tried to break the blockage, police and military police used tear gas to disperse the demonstrators, including journalists, clashed with rioters, and detained 20 people. A group of police officers was also without uniform undercover. An SLD member was supposedly beaten and arrested by the police but video footage indicated that he attacked and injured a police officer. [size=several thousand]

On 5 June 2020, a journalist was attacked with a water bottle, verbally assaulted and forced to erase her camera's memory by unidentified individuals in the Bas de la Riviere neighborhood, Saint Denis (Reunion) while covering a murder scene. [size=no report]

SOURCE: AFP; AP; Ziarul de Iasi; Newsweek.ro; Digi24
NOTES: On 16 September 2021, around 11 men attacked and beat two filmmakers and one activist who were filming a documentary about illegal logging in Panaci, Suceava county. The activist's face was severely injured, while the cameras used for filming were damaged and recordings were erased. The journalists claim that the forest engineer and the owner of the forest also participated in their beating. [size=around 11]
On March 9th 2018, a bus full of foreign journalists and activists was attacked by a mob of Chechens while traveling from Ingushetia to Chechnya. No fatalities reported

On 11 October 2021, an unknown number of high school students in Makhachkala physically attacked a television crew who came to film a report on the killing in a fight, earlier in the day, of a student of the school. The assailants severely beat the crew's cameraman, who was hospitalized as a result of the attack. [size=no report]

SOURCE: Agence de Presse Senegalaise; Sud Quotidien (Senegal)

NOTES: On 3 August 2020, supporters of a Muslim leader attacked the office of a local newspaper in Dakar city (Dakar Plateau, Dakar), after the newspaper published information saying that their leader contracted the coronavirus. They damaged the office of the Editor-in-Chief, as well as equipment, including seven computers and a TV set. Six suspects were reportedly arrested in connection with that incident. [size=at least 6]

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: PASTEF: Patriots of Senegal for Work, Ethics and Fraternity

On 25 October 2021, the staff of a private media outlet engaged in fist fight with the gendarmerie forces and tax agents in Dakar city (Plateau, Dakar) as they resisted seizure of their equipment over unpaid taxes. [size=no report]

On 2 March 2020, after a fake report that there was going to be an LGBT Pride Parade in Leskovac, Serbia, rioters, mostly high-schoolers, took to the streets. They physically attacked one reporter, shoved, and threw eggs at the police. [size=no report]

On 8 July 2020, thousands of demonstrators clashed with the police in Belgrade, Serbia. Demonstrations started when the president announced stronger measures against the coronavirus and a weekend-long curfew, weeks after the measures were dropped in order to hold election. Several journalists were attacked by police while reporting. [size=thousands]

The rally was organized by Start-Change and URI. Masked men attacked and threatened those who rallied. When a group of men stated throwing stones in the crowd, the demonstrators caught and beat one of them. Several journalists were attacked by the counter-demonstrators. [size=no report]

29 September 2018: The editor of Awareness Times newspaper, John Korama was assaulted by vigilantes of the ruling SLPP in the full glare of the police and the Chairman of the SLPP, while he was covering a bye-election at mile-14 in Tonko Limba.

On 5 November 2020, around 500 demonstrators, organized by Anonymous Slovenia, clashed with police in Ljubljana while demonstrating against strict measures, including a curfew, imposed to curb the spread of the coronavirus. Demonstrators threw cobbles and bottles at police, injuring four policemen. 10 demonstrators were arrested and one photojournalist was purposefully hit by a demonstrator while reporting. On 29 September 2021, around 10.000 demonstrators rallied in Ljubljana, Slovenia, against coronavirus passes, that would require immunity or a negative test to the virus. They clashed with the police and attacked journalists. Police responded with tear gas and water cannons in order to disperse the demonstrators. [size=around 10000]
Three rooms in the headquarters of Shacab, an independent newspaper in northeast Somalias semi-autonomous region of Puntland, were damaged after assailants threw gasoline-fueled bombs.

About a hundred people staged a demonstration in front of the SSC/Khatumo State office in Buhoodle town on 14/01. Available reports indicated that the demonstration was organized by a group of pro-Puntland elders hailing from Dhulbahante/Rer Hagar sub-clan. The protestors stormed the SSC/Khatumo radio premise and destroyed furniture, computers and printers.

28 May. There was a violent demonstration conducted in Lasanod in protest of the Somaliland administration. One person was killed and more than 50 others including three journalists were arrested. SLP dispersed the protestors. Movement of vehicles was restricted and most of the businesses in Lasanod were closed.
A reporter is taken hostage by the supporters and members of a controversial school.

Pupils at New Eisleben Secondary School stoned a Cape Argus photographer's vehicle on Wednesday morning during violent protests against the school's principal. Garbage was also dumped in the schools corridors. Upon arriving, fired a tear gas canister to disperse the pupils.

About 500 residents of Clarke Estate blockaded 35th Street with burning tires and stones after law enforcement officers demolished the shack next to the council-owned Rooiberg Court flats. Taxi drivers riot after city officials block the road to taxi vehicles. Journalists are assaulted by the demonstrators and locals are injured.

NOTES: An Independent Media photographer was assaulted and pelted with stones by protesting students at Wits University on Wednesday morning.
Students returning to classes and journalists recording the protests are assaulted by rioting students.

Police and journalists came under attack from a group of students who threw stones at the Durban University of Technology. Police fired rubber bullets and stun grenades at protesters.
Police and students clashed at the Westville campus of the University of KwaZulu-Natal in protests that led to between four and six arrests, including that of one reporter.

In Coligny, three houses were set alight and property damaged after residents continued to protest following the death of a teenage boy. A Photographer was manhandled by the owner of one of the houses that was set alight.

On 29 May 2017, foreign-owned shops were looted in a violent demonstration that erupted in KwaMashu, Durban. Police came under fire when they responded to the chaos. Demonstrators stoned journalists' cars as they entered the township. [size=no report]

A senior Netwerk24 photographer was assaulted and robbed of all his belongings by protesters in Mooi Uitsig, Kleinmond. Violent protests have occurred as informal settlement residents express displeasure that a local resident had not been awarded a tender to clean up the town's streets.

On 4 April 2020, about 50 demonstrators barricaded roads with stones, preventing journalists from leaving the area, in Ulundi (Zululand, KwaZulu-Natal), demanding water and the district mayor to address them. [size=about 50]
